data.title: Geoff Love and His Orchestra play BIG WAR MOVIE THEMES LP 1971. Mint condition. "Where Eagles Dare", "Battle Of Britain", "The Great Escape", "Lawrence Of Arabia", "River Kwai March", etc. Check audio
data.meta_description: Here is THE no.1 holy grail. Most of you would have forgotten all about it until you  watched Al Murray’s TV show about British War films. data.text:
Description

Here is THE no.1 holy grail. Most of you would have forgotten all about it until you watched Al Murray’s TV show about British War films.

This is truly magnificent, fairly faithful renditions of some great films with that little Geoff Love twist.

Check the exclusive video of the LP for sale!

Check the exclusive video of the LP for sale!

Check full album:

Check full album:

https://music.youtube.com/playlist?list=OLAK5uy_k1zfp_NFRxa9O_7xCBdd7XrAm4JO5XsQ8&feature=gws_kp_album&feature=gws_kp_artist

Check full album:

Label: Music For Pleasure <MFP>

Tracklist:

A1 Colonel Bogey Introducing Excerpts From River Kwai March

Written-By – K.J. Alford*, Arnold*

A2

Theme From “Lawrence Of Arabia”

Written-By – Jarre*

A3

The Guns Of Navarone

Written-By – Tiomkin*, Webster*

A4

Theme From “Battle Of Britain”

Written-By – Goodwin*

A5

The Longest Day

Written-By – Anka*

A6

Theme From “Where Eagles Dare”

Written-By – Goodwin*

B1

633 Squadron

Written-By – Goodwin*

B2

The Dam Busters

Written-By – Coates*

B3

The Great Escape March

Written-By – Stillman*, Bernstein*

B4

The Green Berets Theme

Written-By – Rozsa*

B5

Theme From “Is Paris Burning?”

Written-By – Jarre*

B6

Theme From “Reach For The Sky”

Written-By – Addison*

5.0 out of 5 stars Geoff Love and His Orchestra play BIG WAR MOVIE THEMES

I first came across this album back in the late seventies as a 12″ vinyl – what we oldies used to call ‘LPs (short for Long Plays). That version, however has 12 tracks. This album will appeal to all lovers of movie soundtracks, even though these aren’t TOS (The Original Soundtrack) versions. Also those (slightly) older music lovers and movie goers with a hankering for a bit of nostalgia will want to play this album again and again ad nauseam. If you don’t fall into this category yourself, but live with someone who does and are considering buying this as a present – you have been warned…!

5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful Nostalgia,

Geoff Love was a well-known dance and TV band leader and friend of Ron Goodwin, whose music he always made a good fist of conducting. This LP is a lot of fun, and I can’t help but smile at the incongruous 60s jazz arrangement in one or two places such as Lawrence of Arabia. Listeners are likely to have soundtrack recordings of their favourites anyway, so theres no harm done. The sound is full, and sounds remarkably fresh. This really is an LO to take the middle aged among us back to bygone days of different musical styles, and say wistfully ‘Oh yes, i remember that..’

5.0 out of 5 stars Superb,

I grew up with this. What a fantastic collection of British and American wartime movie themes. The thing is they’re all great tunes in themselves and only because you (may) associate them with the movie might put you off. Don’t be put off – track after track of beautiful music, some stomping, some poignant. Everyone one a winner in my book !

one of everyone’s favourites, and indeed very popular at the time, was Geoff Love and his Orchestra playing the Big War Movie Themes (1971). These were all haunting and evocative pieces of classical music and many of them are indelibly written into my memory banks. Recently I decided that I wanted to hear those specific versions again and bought the album on vinyl and sure enough it’s still a great listen.

It struck me though, that although I had seen a good number of the films featured, that I hadn’t seen them all. Also, I wondered how well these classic movies stand up when watched with modern eyes some 48 years later. So I’ve decided to watch all 12 movies in the order they appear on the album and rate the movie along with it’s historical accuracy and depiction of conflict. With modern offerings like Saving Private Ryan, Letters from Iwo Jima, Band of Brothers and Fury the benchmark for modern war films, it will be very interesting to see how they stand up.
